title: N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 21 ยง 1211.150 - Index of dangerous articles
content:
N.Y. Comp. Codes R. & Regs. Tit. 21 ยง 1211.150 - Index of dangerous articles

State Regulations
(a) How to use the index. (1)

To determine which restrictions, if any, apply to the transportation of a dangerous article known by name-e.g., acetone: (i) locate name of dangerous article (as
noted on shipping papers) in the alphabetical listing of dangerous articles
which follows; (ii)
in column 2, note commodity classification. (Acetone is classified as a flammable
liquid.); (iii)
in column 3, note
"D.O.T. label in use as of December 31, 1968." (For example, acetone bears a
red label.); (iv)
in column 4, find
section numbers which refer directly to applicable restrictions. (For acetone, references are 1211.76 and 1211.77.); (v) turn to section number referenced in
column 4. Then, going down the left-hand margin of the referenced section, locate the section number or numbers also indicated in column 4. (In our
example, section
1211.76
limits the capacity and
type of container and quantity per vehicle which may be transported via either
a tunnel, the George Washington Bridge Lower Level or George Washington Bridge

Expressway while making due provision for the passage of empty containers, and
prohibiting the passage of loaded or empty tank vehicles. Section
1211.77
imposes slightly different
restrictions, based upon the use of inside containers.)
(2)

To determine which restrictions, if any, apply to the transportation of a dangerous article whose specific name is not
known, but whose general class is indicated in the shipping papers: (i) locate, in the alphabetical index column, the name of the general class of commodity with which the unnamed article is
normally identified, e.g., Flammable Liquid (N.O.S. or N.O.I., or N.O.I.B.N.), Corrosive Liquid (N.O.S. or N.O.I. or N.O.I.B.N.), etc. (ii)

Proceed as in (a) (iii), (iv) and (v)
above. (b) Index of dangerous articles. Article

Note: No tank vehicle is allowed
passage if it is used for the transportation of aqua ammonia or ammonium
hydroxide with more than 10.5 percent by weight of ammonia
(NH
3
) or having a gravity exceeding 17 degrees Baume. No
restriction exists, however, for empty tank vehicles which last contained such
aqua ammonia or ammonium hydroxide, provided the tank vehicle is shown on the
shipping paper to be empty, that is, drained of the material it last contained
with residue not in excess of 50 gallons. Note: No tank vehicle is allowed
passage if it is used for the transportation of formaldehyde solution. No
restriction exists for empty tank vehicles which last contained formaldehyde
solution, provided the tank vehicle is shown on the shipping paper to be empty, that is, drained of the material it last contained with residue not in excess
of 50 gallons. Note: A tank vehicle used for the
transportation of liquid oxygen is not allowed passage. An empty tank vehicle
which last contained liquid oxygen is, however, allowed passage, provided the
vehicle is shown on the shipping papers to be empty, that is, with residue not
in excess of 50 gallons. Notes
